meanings.def: to move or travel from one place to another
examples: + adv./prep. She went into her room and shut the door behind her.
I have to go to Rome on business.
She has gone to China (= is now in China or is on her way there).
She has been to China (= she went to China and has now returned).
Are you going home for Christmas?
go to do something She has gone to see her sister this weekend.
Could you go and get me a towel?
I'm going to Spain this year.
It's a long way to go just to see a couple of reefs.
She's gone to Brazil on vacation.
The weather was pretty bad when we went to Boston last year.

meanings.def: to move or travel, especially with somebody else, to a particular place or in order to be present at an event
examples: go (to something) Are you going to Dave's party?
Who else is going?
go with somebody His dog goes everywhere with him.
go (to something) (with somebody) He invited her to go with him to the concert.

meanings.def: to move or travel in a particular way or over a particular distance
examples: + adv./prep. He's going too fast.
They went farther north into the mountains.
+ noun We had gone about fifty miles when the car broke down.
Slow down—you're going too fast.
We had gone many miles without seeing another car.

meanings.def: to move in a particular way or while doing something else
examples: She crashed into a waiter and his tray of drinks went flying.
The car went skidding off the road into a ditch.
She went sobbing up the stairs.
I tripped and went tumbling down the stairs.
Don't go charging in there!

meanings.def: to leave one place in order to reach another
examples: I must be going now.
They came at six and went at nine.
Has she gone yet?
He's been gone an hour (= he left an hour ago).
When does the train go?
After they'd gone there was an awkward silence.
Don't go—I want to talk to you.
Here's a list of things to remember before you go.
The train goes in a few minutes' time.
They went at about nine o'clock.
What time did they go?

meanings.def: to leave a place and do something different
examples: to go on a journey/tour/trip/cruise
Richard has gone on leave for two weeks.
(British English) to go on holiday
(North American English) to go on vacation

meanings.def: to visit or attend a place for a particular purpose
examples: to go to school/college/university
(British English) I have to go to hospital for an operation.
(North American English) I have to go to the hospital.
(British English) to go to the cinema
(North American English) to go to the movies
to go to prison/jail (= to be sent there as punishment for a crime)
He goes to work by bus.
I think you should go to the doctor's.
Do you go to church (= regularly attend church services)?
I always go to the gym before work.

meanings.def: to look at a particular page or website
examples: go on something She went on Facebook and changed her relationship status.
go to something To find out what the terms mean, go to the glossary.

meanings.def: to leave a place or travel to a place in order to take part in an activity or a sport
examples: go for something to go for a walk
to go for a ride/drive/run/swim
Shall we go for a drink (= at a pub or bar) after work?
go doing to go swimming/fishing/jogging
I have to go shopping this afternoon.
We're going sailing on Saturday.
We went walking on the beach.

meanings.def: to be sent or passed somewhere
examples: I want this memo to go to all managers.

meanings.def: used to talk about how quickly or slowly time seems to pass
examples: Hasn't the time gone quickly?
Half an hour went past while we were sitting there.
The cruise went very quickly.

meanings.def: to stop existing; to be lost or stolen
examples: Has your headache gone yet?
I left my bike outside the library and when I came out again it had gone.

meanings.def: to lead or extend in a particular direction
examples: + adv./prep. Where does this road go?
The trail goes north at this point.
go from something to something I want a rope that will go from the top window to the ground.

meanings.def: to have as a usual or correct position; to be placed
examples: This dictionary goes on the top shelf.
Where do you want the piano to go (= be put)?

meanings.def: used to say that something does/did not fit into a particular place or space
examples: My clothes won't all go in that one suitcase.
He tried to push his hand through the gap but it wouldn't go.

meanings.def: used to talk about how well or badly something makes progress or succeeds
examples: ‘How did the interview go?’ ‘It went well, thank you.’
Did everything go smoothly?
How's it going (= is your life enjoyable, successful, etc. at the moment)?
The way things are going, the company will be bankrupt by the end of the year.

meanings.def: used in many expressions to show that somebody/something has reached a particular state/is no longer in a particular state
examples: go to something She went to sleep.
The US and Mexico went to war in 1846.
go into something The law went into effect on 1 August.
go on something Shares went on sale this morning.
They're threatening to go on strike again.
go out of something That colour has gone out of fashion.

meanings.def: to become different in a particular way, especially a bad way
examples: to go crazy/mad/nuts/insane
She's beginning to go blind.
He suddenly went quiet.
The company went bankrupt last year.
The two little girls went missing over a week ago.
Her hair is going grey.
The children went wild with excitement.
I can't believe I'm going bald—I'm only thirty!
She went bright red with embarrassment.
The milk has gone sour.

meanings.def: to live or move around in a particular state
examples: to go naked/barefoot
She cannot bear the thought of children going hungry.

meanings.def: to spend a period of time in a particular way
examples: They went for two weeks without receiving any news.

meanings.def: to not be noticed, reported, etc.
examples: Pippa's absence went unnoticed.
Police are worried that many crimes go unreported.
In these traditional stories, no crime goes unpunished.
Customer service calls went unanswered.

meanings.def: to make a particular sound or movement
examples: + noun The gun went ‘bang’.
+ adv./prep. She went like this with her hand.

meanings.def: to be sounded as a signal or warning
examples: The whistle went for the end of the game.

meanings.def: if a number will go into another number, it is contained in that number an exact number of times
examples: (+ adj.) 3 into 12 goes 4 times.
7 into 15 won’t go.
(North American English) 7 into 15 doesn’t go.
go into something 7 won’t go into 15.

meanings.def: to combine well with something
examples: go with something Does this jacket go with this skirt?
go (together) Those colours don’t really go (together).
Leeks and potatoes go well together in a soup.
That tie goes well with that shirt.

meanings.def: used to talk about what tune or words a song or poem has or what happens in a story
examples: + adv./prep. How does that song go?
I forget how the next line goes.
go that… The story goes that she's been married five times.

meanings.def: to say
examples: I asked ‘How much?’ and he goes, ‘Fifty’ and I go, ‘Fifty? You must be joking!’

meanings.def: to start an activity
examples: I'll say ‘One, two, three, go!’ as a signal for you to start.
As soon as he gets here we're ready to go.

meanings.def: if a machine goes, it works
examples: This clock doesn't go.
What makes it go?

meanings.def: used to talk about wanting to get rid of somebody/something
examples: The old sofa will have to go.
He's useless—he'll have to go.

meanings.def: to get worse; to become damaged or stop working correctly
examples: Her sight is beginning to go.
His mind is going (= he is losing his mental powers).
I was driving home when my brakes went.

meanings.def: to die. People say ‘go’ to avoid saying ‘die’.
examples: You can't take your money with you when you go.

meanings.def: when money goes, it is spent or used for something
examples: I don't know where the money goes!
go on something Most of my salary goes on the rent.
go to do something The money will go to finance a new community centre.

meanings.def: to be sold
examples: We won't let the house go for less than $200 000.
There was usually some bread going cheap (= being sold cheaply) at the end of the day.

meanings.def: to be willing to pay a particular amount of money for something
examples: He's offered £3 000 for the car and I don't think he'll go any higher.
I'll go to $1 000 but that's my limit.

meanings.def: to help; to play a part in doing something
examples: This all goes to prove my theory.
It (= what has just happened) just goes to show you can't always tell how people are going to react.

meanings.def: to be available
examples: There just aren't any jobs going in this area.

meanings.def: to use a toilet
examples: Do you need to go, Billy?

meanings.def: anything that somebody says or does is accepted or allowed, even if it shocks or surprises people
examples: Almost anything goes these days.

meanings.def: in comparison with the average person, thing, etc.
examples: As teachers go, he's not bad.

meanings.def: to be nearly a particular age, time or number
examples: It was going on (for) midnight.

meanings.def: used to show what somebody intends to do in the future
examples: We're going to buy a house when we've saved enough money.

meanings.def: used to show that something is likely to happen very soon or in the future
examples: I think I'm going to faint.
If the drought continues there's going to be a famine.

meanings.def: used to tell or warn somebody not to do something
examples: Don't go getting yourself into trouble.

meanings.def: something that is enough for a short time
examples: £50 should be enough to be going on with.

meanings.def: to make a very great effort to get something or do something
used to show that you are angry or annoyed that somebody has done something stupid
examples: Trust him to go and mess things up!
Why did you have to go and upset your mother like that?
You've really gone and done it (= done something very stupid) now!

meanings.def: to suddenly become very angry
examples: Now and again she really goes off on one.

meanings.def: used to express the fact that you do not believe something, or that you think something is bad
examples: Go on with you—you’re never forty. You don’t look a day over thirty.

meanings.def: (to have) many/not many advantages
examples: You're young, intelligent, attractive—you have a lot going for you!

meanings.def: not possible or allowed
examples: If the bank won't lend us the money it's no go, I'm afraid.

meanings.def: used to say that you do not want to talk about something in any more detail because you do not even want to think about it
examples: Don't ask me to choose. I don't want to go there.
‘There was a problem with his parents, wasn't there?’ ‘Don't even go there!’

meanings.def: what you say to tell people to start a race
to start with; for now
examples: ‘One slice or two?’ ‘Just one to be going on with.’

meanings.def: that remains; still left
examples: I only have one exam to go.

meanings.def: if you buy cooked food to go in a restaurant or shop, you buy it to take away and eat somewhere else
examples: Two pizzas to go.

meanings.def: the way somebody behaves towards other people will affect the way those people behave towards them in the future
something that is not fashionable now will become fashionable again in the future
used to ask what action somebody should take, especially in order to improve the difficult situation that they are in
used by a soldier who is guarding a place to order somebody to say who they are
examples: Halt, who goes there?

idioms.def: anything that somebody says or does is accepted or allowed, even if it shocks or surprises people
examples: Almost anything goes these days.

idioms.def: in comparison with the average person, thing, etc.
examples: As teachers go, he's not bad.

idioms.def: to be nearly a particular age, time or number
examples: It was going on (for) midnight.

idioms.def: used to show what somebody intends to do in the future
examples: We're going to buy a house when we've saved enough money.
I think I'm going to faint.
If the drought continues there's going to be a famine.

idioms.def: used to tell or warn somebody not to do something
examples: Don't go getting yourself into trouble.

idioms.idiom: enough/something to be going on with
idioms.def: something that is enough for a short time
examples: £50 should be enough to be going on with.

idioms.idiom: go all out for something | go all out to do something
idioms.def: to make a very great effort to get something or do something
used to show that you are angry or annoyed that somebody has done something stupid
examples: Trust him to go and mess things up!
Why did you have to go and upset your mother like that?
You've really gone and done it (= done something very stupid) now!

idioms.def: to suddenly become very angry
examples: Now and again she really goes off on one.

idioms.def: used to express the fact that you do not believe something, or that you think something is bad
examples: Go on with you—you’re never forty. You don’t look a day over thirty.

idioms.idiom: (have) a lot, nothing, etc. going for you
idioms.def: (to have) many/not many advantages
examples: You're young, intelligent, attractive—you have a lot going for you!

idioms.def: not possible or allowed
examples: If the bank won't lend us the money it's no go, I'm afraid.

idioms.def: used to say that you do not want to talk about something in any more detail because you do not even want to think about it
examples: Don't ask me to choose. I don't want to go there.
‘There was a problem with his parents, wasn't there?’ ‘Don't even go there!’

idioms.def: what you say to tell people to start a race
to start with; for now
examples: ‘One slice or two?’ ‘Just one to be going on with.’

idioms.def: that remains; still left
examples: I only have one exam to go.
Two pizzas to go.

idioms.def: the way somebody behaves towards other people will affect the way those people behave towards them in the future

idioms.idiom: where does somebody go from here?
idioms.def: used to ask what action somebody should take, especially in order to improve the difficult situation that they are in
used by a soldier who is guarding a place to order somebody to say who they are
examples: Halt, who goes there?

meanings.def: a person’s turn to move or play in a game or an activity
examples: Whose go is it?
It's your go.
‘How much is it to play?’ ‘It's 50p a go.’
go on something Can I have a go on your new bike?

meanings.def: an attempt at doing something
examples: It took three goes to get it right.
I doubt if he'll listen to advice from me, but I'll give it a go (= I'll try but I don't think I will succeed).

meanings.def: energy and enthusiasm
examples: Mary's always got plenty of go.

meanings.def: in one single attempt or try
examples: She blew out the candles at one go.

meanings.def: to be very busy or full of activity
examples: It was all go in the office today.

meanings.def: to be planned and possible or allowed
examples: I'm not sure if Friday's trip is a go.

meanings.def: to be very active and busy
examples: I've been on the go all day.
Having four children keeps her on the go.

meanings.def: used to ask somebody to be reasonable
examples: I just wanted to say, ‘Hey mate, fair go!’

meanings.def: (to give somebody/get) fair treatment that gives you the same chance as somebody else
examples: Are minority students getting a fair shake at college?
We need a government that cares about equity and a fair go for all.

meanings.def: at the first, second, etc. attempt
examples: I passed my driving test first go.

meanings.def: to attack somebody physically
examples: There were about seven of them standing round him, all waiting to have a go.

meanings.def: to make an attempt to do something
examples: ‘I can't start the engine.’ ‘Let me have a go.’
I'll have a go at fixing it tonight.
You should have a go at answering all the questions.

meanings.def: to criticize somebody or complain about somebody
examples: The boss had a go at me for being late for work.
The government are always having a go at teachers.

meanings.def: to be in the middle of an activity or a project
examples: The award-winning novelist often has three or four books on the go at once.

meanings.def: all together on one occasion
examples: I'd rather do the journey in one go, and not stop on the way.
They ate the packet of biscuits all in one go.

meanings.def: to stop holding on to something
examples: Leave go of my arm—you're hurting me!

meanings.def: to stop holding somebody/something
examples: Don't let go of the rope.
Don't let the rope go.
Let go! You're hurting me!

meanings.def: to give up an idea or an attitude, or control of something
examples: It's time to let go of the past.
It's time to let the past go.

meanings.def: to stop holding somebody/something
examples: Don't let the rope go.
Don't let go of the rope.
Let go! You're hurting me!

meanings.def: to give up an idea or an attitude, or control of something
examples: It's time to let the past go.
It's time to let go of the past.

meanings.def: to be successful in something
examples: We've had a few problems in our marriage, but we're both determined to make a go of it.

idioms.idiom: at a/one go | at/in a single go
idioms.def: in one single attempt or try
examples: She blew out the candles at one go.

idioms.def: to be very busy or full of activity
examples: It was all go in the office today.

idioms.def: to be planned and possible or allowed
examples: I'm not sure if Friday's trip is a go.

idioms.def: to be very active and busy
examples: I've been on the go all day.
Having four children keeps her on the go.

idioms.def: used to ask somebody to be reasonable
examples: I just wanted to say, ‘Hey mate, fair go!’

idioms.def: (to give somebody/get) fair treatment that gives you the same chance as somebody else
examples: Are minority students getting a fair shake at college?
We need a government that cares about equity and a fair go for all.

idioms.def: at the first, second, etc. attempt
examples: I passed my driving test first go.

idioms.def: to attack somebody physically
examples: There were about seven of them standing round him, all waiting to have a go.

idioms.idiom: have a go (at something/at doing something)
idioms.def: to make an attempt to do something
examples: ‘I can't start the engine.’ ‘Let me have a go.’
I'll have a go at fixing it tonight.
You should have a go at answering all the questions.

idioms.def: to criticize somebody or complain about somebody
examples: The boss had a go at me for being late for work.
The government are always having a go at teachers.

idioms.def: to be in the middle of an activity or a project
examples: The award-winning novelist often has three or four books on the go at once.

idioms.def: all together on one occasion
examples: I'd rather do the journey in one go, and not stop on the way.
They ate the packet of biscuits all in one go.

idioms.def: to stop holding on to something
examples: Leave go of my arm—you're hurting me!

idioms.idiom: let go (of somebody/something) | let somebody/something go
idioms.def: to stop holding somebody/something
examples: Don't let go of the rope.
Don't let the rope go.
Let go! You're hurting me!
It's time to let go of the past.
It's time to let the past go.

idioms.idiom: let somebody/something go | let go (of somebody/something)
idioms.def: to stop holding somebody/something
examples: Don't let the rope go.
Don't let go of the rope.
Let go! You're hurting me!
It's time to let the past go.
It's time to let go of the past.

idioms.def: to be successful in something
examples: We've had a few problems in our marriage, but we're both determined to make a go of it.
